titleStmt.title: for droppings
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln
titleStmt.funder: The National Endowment for the Humanities

address.addrLine: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive.

notesStmt.note: The poetic lines on the back of this manuscript thematically resemble part of the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, specifically the final lines of the poem later called "A Song for Occupations," so the date is probably around 1855. The handwriting and ink on the recto and verso appear to be similar, suggesting that they were likely written around the same time. Paper fragments and leftover bits of glue near the bottom of the leaf suggest it was at one point attached to something else.

bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Priests! Until you can explain a paving stone
bibl.orgName: The Charles E. Feinberg Collection of the Papers of Walt Whitman, 1839–1919, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Transcribed from Joel Myerson's The Walt Whitman Archive: A Facsimile of the Poet's Manuscripts, vol. 1, part 2, Garland Publishing, 1993; Primary Source Media's Major American Authors on CD-Rom: Walt Whitman, 1997; digital images of the original.
On the back of this note is a crossed-out manuscript fragment with several lines of poetry.

revisionDesc.change: created new file for verso, added note from EAD entry

body.head: for droppings
body.ab: Poem—embodying the sentiment of perfect happiness, in myself th body and soul being all right—regardless of whatever may happen.
